title: Is Pinkeye a Symptom of COVID-19?

statement: Pinkeye, or conjunctivitis, is a symptom of COVID-19.

says

shark populations in recent decades.
author: Madison Dapcevich

subtitle: If it was carried out, the president's call to finalize the preliminary election results before 16 November would discount ballots cast by Floridians overseas.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: If carried out, President Donald Trump's 12 November proposal to finalize the election night results of two contests in Florida would exclude ballots mailed by U.S. military personnel overseas.

title: Did Clint Eastwood Say Obama Was the
subtitle: Eastwood made something approximating this remark in 2012, following his appearance in support of Mitt Romney at the Republican National Convention.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Clint Eastwood said "one day we will realize that the Barack Obama presidency was the biggest fraud ever perpetrated on the American people.

title: Does This Video Show Caravan Members Tearing Down a Border Fence?
subtitle: Misinformation concerning a group of asylum seekers was prevalent online in October 2018, but a video showing a border fence between Mexico and Guatemala being torn down is real.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a group of asylum seekers tearing down a border fence between Mexico and Guatemala.

title: Was Donald Trump the First President Since 1991 to Speak at the Future Farmers of America Convention?
subtitle: A meme got the basic facts right about President Trump's visit to Indianapolis in October 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In October 2018, Donald Trump became the first sitting U.S. president in 27 years to speak at the national Future Farmers of America national convention.

title: Does This Photograph Show Children Playing 'Pin the Molotov Cocktail on a Cop Car?'
subtitle: Is this picture an example of how "dangerously violent" the left is?  The timing and location are key details.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a child playing "pin the Molotov cocktail on the cop car" at an anarchist book fair.

title: Did Gubernatorial Candidate Stacey Abrams Once Burn the Georgia State Flag?
subtitle: The Democrat's participation in a 1992 protest re-emerged during the hotly-contested Georgia governor's race in October 2018.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Democratic gubernatorial candidate Stacey Abrams burned the Georgia state flag during a protest in 1992.

title: Did Officials in Georgia Stop a Bus Filled with Black Seniors Going to Vote?
subtitle: Activists have accused Jefferson County officials of racially-motivated voter suppression, but officials claim they were enforcing a ban on "political activities" at a Louisville senior center.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: On 15 October 2018, Jefferson County officials stopped a bus filled with seniors from a county-run senior center from going to vote.

title: Did a High School Band Perform a Skit That Depicted Police Officers Being Shot?
subtitle: A half-time performance loosely based on the movie 'John Q' caused widespread controversy in Mississippi and beyond.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The Forest Hill High School band performed a half-time show that depicted police officers being shot.

title: Are Sexual Predators Using 'Fortnite' to Groom Children?
subtitle: New Jersey's Attorney General gave a general warning about 19 popular apps, including Fortnite, but news reports singled out the game even though it was not involved in a September 2018 crackdown.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Law enforcement officials said parents should be worried about sexual predators using gaming apps such as Fortnite to groom children.

title: Do These Photographs Show a Homeless Veteran Dying Under a Bush?
subtitle: "We want to discard the parts of society we don't want, but like plastic, it's never going to go away."
author: Dan Evon
statement: A pair of photographs shows a severely dehydrated homeless veteran on the streets of Los Angeles.

title: Did Senator Richard Blumenthal Misrepresent His Military Service?
subtitle: The Connecticut Democrat admitted making false and misleading claims about his military service record but insisted he had "misspoken."
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Senator Richard Blumenthal misrepresented his record of military service during the Vietnam War.

title: Did These GOP Senators Vote Against Reauthorizing the 'Violence Against Women Act'?
subtitle: Six Republican members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, but not the "ranking member," voted against this particular measure.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: The six Republican "ranking members" of the Senate Judiciary Committee voted against the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act in 2013.

title: Does Nike Make Shoes Featuring the 'All-Seeing Eye' Symbol?
subtitle: If you think that your shoes are watching you, maybe they are ... if you own this particular Nike line.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Nike sells shoes featuring an "All-Seeing Eye" symbol that represents satanism or the Illuminati.

title: Did Levi Strauss Announce a Partnership with Michael Bloomberg to Advocate for Gun Control?
subtitle: Conservative web sites and the NRA gave largely accurate accounts of a September 2018 announcement by the maker of the iconic Levi's jeans.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In September 2018, Levi Strauss announced they would be partnering with businessman Michael Bloomberg to advocate for gun control policies.

title: Did an Ohio Police Officer Say 'Abolishing Slavery Was the Worst Thing' Ever Done?
subtitle: A volunteer officer with the Fairview Park Police Department posted the comments online. He resigned from the department in 2014.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: An Ohio police officer said that slavery should have never been abolished and "these people should be exterminated."

title: Did South Carolina Execute 14-Year-Old George Stinney, Then Declare Him Innocent 70 Years Later?
subtitle: A viral Facebook post offered an accurate account of the conviction and execution of George Stinney Jr., in 1944.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The state of South Carolina executed 14-year-old George Stinney in 1944, but a judge from the same court declared his "innocence" in 2014.

title: The Death of John Crawford III
subtitle: President Donald Trump's renewed criticism of NFL protests prompted the re-emergence on social media of a controversy regarding the 2014 police shooting of a black man in Ohio.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: We evaluate the claims made in a viral 2018 meme about the police shooting death of John Crawford III.

title: Did Celebrity Chef Guy Fieri Feed 5,000 California Wildfire Evacuees?
subtitle: The numbers aren't entirely clear, but the Food Network star certainly coordinated a major relief effort in Redding, California, over two days.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Celebrity chef Guy Fieri fed, or helped to feed, 5,000 people displaced by the 2018 Carr Fire in Shasta County, California.

title: Did This Man Fly Through the Air with a Jet-Powered Hoverboard Strapped to His Feet?
subtitle: A video showing a man flying through the air  is real, but we're skeptical about the claimed speed of 103 mph.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a man flying through the air thanks to a jet-powered engine strapped to his feet.

title: Can a Person Live Off of a Diet of Potatoes and Butter?
subtitle: People could "survive" eating a very limited diet, health experts told us, but they wouldn't get everything their bodies needs to function.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: A person can "survive" living on a diet of nothing but potatoes and butter.

title: Did N.C. Republican Candidate Russell Walker Say 'God Is a Racist and a White Supremacist'?
subtitle: Russell Walker, a Republican candidate for the North Carolina statehouse, has made no secret of his racist and anti-Semitic views.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Russell Walker, a candidate running as a Republican in the North Carolina general election, said 'God Is a Racist and White Supremacist' among other racist comments.

title: Was a Cartoonist Fired for an Anti-Trump Drawing?
subtitle: Rob Rogers was let go after his newspaper rejected a number of cartoons, but not all of them had to do with President Donald Trump.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Rob Rogers was fired by his newspaper after creating a cartoon which featured President Donald Trump snatching a child immigrant.

title: Did Bernie Sanders Support Dumping Nuclear Waste in a 'Poor Latino Community'?
subtitle: A conservative group's Facebook meme gets some basic facts right but leaves out important context.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Sen. Bernie Sanders once supported a proposal to "dump nuclear waste" in the "poor Latino community" of Sierra Blanca, Texas.

title: Is the EPA Allowing for the Approval of New Asbestos-Containing Products?
subtitle: The Environmental Protection Agency will be allowing for potential new uses of asbestos, while limiting the scope of studies that assess its risk.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The Environmental Protection Agency will allow new asbestos products to enter the market.

title: Did the 'Distracted Boyfriend' Meme Come From a 1920's Silent Film?
subtitle: Saying that Charlie Chaplin invented the "distracted boyfriend" meme is a bit of a stretch, but an early version of the viral image can be spotted in the 1922 short film "Pay Day."
author: Dan Evon
statement: A still from a 1920s Charlie Chaplin silent film resembles an online meme popularized nearly a century later.

title: Was James Doohan Shot Six Times on D-Day?
subtitle: A popular meme recounting the actor's involvement with the D-Day invasion at Normandy is largely accurate, but some of the details are a little hazy.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Actor James Doohan, best known for his role as "Scotty" from the original Star Trek, was shot six times during D-Day.

title: Have Children Been Fined for Operating Lemonade Stands?
subtitle: Country Time promoted a "legal-ade" fund for kids fined over lemonade stands, but has that ever actually happened?
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Children have been fined for operating lemonade stands without a permit, or ordered to obtain expensive permits.

title: Did a Tennessee Hardware Store Put Up a 'No Gays Allowed' Sign?
subtitle: The store that put up the sign in 2015 was back in the news several years later when it celebrated a Supreme Court decision in favor of a bakery that refused to make a wedding cake for a same-sex couple.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A Tennessee hardware store put up a sign reading "no gays allowed."

title: Are Rosaries Being Taken from Immigrants at the U.S.-Mexico Border?
subtitle: Rosaries are among personal belongings confiscated from immigrants when they are arrested at the southern border of the United States.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Immigration authorities are taking rosaries away from immigrants at the border.

title: Is This a Picture of ICE's 'Special Prison Bus for Babies'?
subtitle: A transport vehicle outfitted for children held at an immigrant detention facility has been described as a "prison bus for babies" by some.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A photograph depicts a "special prison bus for babies" used by ICE at an immigrant detention facility.

title: Was a German Football Club Banned After Failing to Give a Nazi Salute?
subtitle: News reports of a German football club's getting banned in 1934 after failing to give the Nazi salute are real, but the team's actions were not in protest of the Third Reich.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A German football club was banned from playing games outside Germany in 1934, after they failed to give a Nazi salute.

title: Does the U.S. Experience Far More School Shootings Than Any Other Country?
subtitle: CNN got the basic facts about international school shooting frequencies right, albeit in a list that omitted some significant countries.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: The experienced many times more school shootings between 2009 and 2018 than 27 other countries combined.

title: Were AR-15s Used in Every Major Mass Shooting in the United States After Aurora?
subtitle: An attempt to link the rifle to several major mass attacks circulated widely online in the hours following a school shooting in Texas.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: AR-15 rifles were used to commit every major mass shooting in the United States since a 2012 attack in an Aurora, Colorado movie theater.

title: Was an Oklahoma Woman Killed By a Pack of Small Dachshunds?
subtitle: A woman was fatally mauled by a pack of dogs that mainly consisted of dachshund mixes of varying sizes.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A woman in Oklahoma was killed by a pack of small dachshunds.

title: Did President Trump Establish a 'Religious Office' in the White House?
subtitle: A Facebook meme gets the basic facts right but misses some important context.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In May 2018, President Donald Trump established a "religious office" to give religious groups a "voice in government."

title: Is This a Vampire Squid Turning Itself Inside Out?
subtitle: A video showing a cephalopod contorting to confuse predators ended up confusing some viewers, as well.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a vampire squid turning itself inside out, revealing sharp barbs on the underside of its hood.

title: Camels Crossing the Sea?
subtitle: A video showing a group of camels swimming through ocean waters doesn't show what it claims - but what it describes is real.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a group of camels swimming through the sea.

title: Is This a Velvet Cowkiller Ant?
subtitle: The red velvet ant, or cowkiller ant, is a wingless wasp with an extremely painful sting.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Photographs show a velvet cow killer ant.

title: Did a Man Lock His Head in a Cage to Quit Smoking?
subtitle: Photographs showing a man wearing an "anti-smoking cage" around his head may seem strange, but they originated with a genuine news report.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A Russian man locked his head in a cage in an attempt to stop smoking.

title: Did a Daredevil Ride a Motorcycle Across Lake Como?
subtitle: A viral Facebook post showing a man riding his motorbike across Lake Como failed to mention that it was outfitted with special skis.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a man riding a motorcycle over Lake Como.

title: Does a Photograph Show a Real Giant Manta Ray?
subtitle: A photograph showing a giant manta ray caught in 1933 features the work of a taxidermist.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a giant manta ray, or devil fish, that was caught in 1933.

title: Did Donald Trump Once Fight Against Installing Sprinklers in New York Apartment Buildings?
subtitle: A viral meme accurately describes the future president's lobbying efforts, but it leaves out the fact that his stance on sprinklers later softened.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In 1999, Donald Trump lobbied against mandatory sprinklers for apartment buildings in New York, including his own Trump Tower.

title: Are These Daredevils Playing Tennis on an Airplane?
subtitle: A photograph of two wing walkers holding tennis rackets on top of an airborne airplane is genuine, but they weren't playing a real game of tennis.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows two daredevils playing tennis on the wings of an airplane.

title: Was Al Sharpton's Brother Arrested for Murder After Speaking at a March for Our Lives Rally?
subtitle: Kenneth Glasgow has been accused of driving the car when his passenger shot and killed a woman.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Al Sharpton's brother has been arrested for murder after participating in a March for Our Lives rally in Alabama.

title: Did an Instagram Post by Rihanna Cause Snapchat's Stock Market Value to Fall?
subtitle: The megastar's exhortation to her 61 million followers to "throw away" the app likely did make a significant contribution to a $750 million one-day loss.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Rihanna's Instagram message to followers to throw away the Snapchat app caused the company's share value to fall by hundreds of millions of dollars in one day.

title: Was a Karl Marx Banknote Released in Germany?
subtitle: A photograph showing a young woman holding a Karl Marx bill (worth 0) is real, but it is a souvenir note rather than a genuine article of currency.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A zero value banknote was released in honor of Karl Marx's 200th birthday.

title: Is Toys R Us Closing All Locations, Not Accepting Gift Cards?
subtitle: Ongoing business troubles for the toy chain led to rumors that gift cards could soon be (or already are) of no value.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Toys R Us is closing all stores and gift cards are soon-to-be or no longer have value.

title: Does an 'Empty Shoes' Memorial in Washington, D.C. Represent 7,000 Children Killed by Guns Since Sandy Hook?
subtitle: Seven thousand pairs of empty shoes on display at the U.S. Capitol were intended to represent child victims of gun violence since the Sandy Hook shooting.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: A temporary memorial at the U.S. Capitol displays a pair of empty shoes to illustrate the 7,000 children killed by guns since the December 2012 Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting.

title: Are McDonald's Restaurants Flipping Their Iconic Golden Arches Upside Down for Women's Day?
subtitle: The fast food chain is celebrating International Women's Day by turning its iconic golden arches into a "W."
author: Bethania Palma
statement: McDonald's restaurants are turning their iconic gold arches upside down to celebrate International Women's Day.

title: Did Amnesty International 'Officially Declare' Donald Trump a 'Human Rights Violator'?
subtitle: The group didn't formally give the U.S. president that label, but it used strong language in accusing him of human rights breaches.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In February 2018, Amnesty International officially declared U.S. President Donald Trump a "human rights violator."

title: Did Wayne LaPierre Say There Should Be 'No Guns in Schools, Period'?
subtitle: A quote attributed to Wayne LaPierre of the NRA was abbreviated in a slightly misleading fashion.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: In 1999, Wayne LaPierre of the NRA said there should be no guns in American schools "period."

title: Gun Manufacturers Can't Be Sued For Crimes Committed With Their Products?
subtitle: There are almost no circumstances under which someone can sue a manufacturer in civil court for a crime committed with a gun.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Gun manufacturers have legal immunity from being sued for crimes committed with the weapons or ammunition they sell.

title: Did President Trump Revoke Gun Background Checks for Mentally Ill People?
subtitle: In February 2017, President Trump repealed an Obama-era regulation that would have made it easier to flag the potential sale of firearms to people with certain mental illnesses.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: President Trump signed a bill blocking Obama-era background checks that would have made it easier to flag mentally ill potential gun purchasers.

title: Did a Utah School Bar Girls From Refusing Boys' Dance Requests?
subtitle: The rules for Kanesville Elementary's school dance attracted national attention before being "re-examined" by officials.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Girls at a Utah elementary school were required to say "yes" when asked to dance at a school event.

title: Did Pope Francis Allow a Little Girl to Sit with Him During a Homily?
subtitle: The story was essentially true, but it picked up some embellishment along the way.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Pope Francis allowed a little girl with Down Syndrome to sit with him as he gave a homily.

title: Did a Professor Flunk a Student for Correctly Saying that Australia Is a Country?
subtitle: Ashley Arnold attracted media attention after challenging - and triumphing over - her instructor's faulty grasp of geography.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: An instructor failed a student for saying that Australia was a country rather than a continent.

title: Was Football Star Brian Banks Wrongfully Convicted of Rape?
subtitle: The legal ordeal of a California high school football star was turned into a meme that misrepresented key details of his case.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Star football player Brian Banks was convicted of raping a woman who confessed on Facebook that she fabricated her accusation -- after he served six years in prison.

title: New California Law Bars Employers From Asking About Criminal History?
subtitle: California joined nine other states in enacting a "ban-the-box" law intended to reduce recidivism.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A new California law bars employers from inquiring about criminal backgrounds.

title: Is It Possible to Get High from Secondhand Marijuana Smoke?
subtitle: It is possible to experience some psychoactive effects from secondhand exposure to marijuana smoke, but you'd really have to put effort into it.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Exposure to secondhand marijuana smoke will get you high and potentially show up in a drug test.

title: Is There a New 'Lucky Charms Frosted Flakes' Mashup Cereal?
subtitle: General Mills will be selling a new Lucky Charms cereal that incorporates glazed cornflakes.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A "Lucky Charms Frosted Flakes" cereal will soon be available.

title: Woman Almost Loses Leg After Cutting Herself Shaving?
subtitle: Viral reports of a woman's harrowing experience with a life-threatening skin infection are mostly true, but omitted some important details.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: After shaving her legs, a woman developed a life-threatening skin infection that required the removal of massive amounts of skin and muscle tissue.

title: Probation for Child Rape Vs. Prison for Stealing Ribs?
subtitle: A Facebook meme accurately presents the basic facts of two very different but equally controversial cases.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A billionaire avoided jail despite raping his infant daughter, while another man was sentenced to 50 years in jail for stealing a rack of ribs.

title: Can Marijuana Use Lead to Simultaneous Screaming and Vomiting?
subtitle: A story employed the colorful portmanteau term "scromiting" to describe an illness potentially related to marijuana usage.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: An increase in documented cases of people "scromiting" (screaming while vomiting) is linked to chronic heavy marijuana use.

title: Does Switching Your Twitter Location to Germany Block Nazi Content?
subtitle: Changing your Twitter account's country to Germany does cause some far-right profiles to be withheld from view.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Changing your Twitter profile's country setting to Germany will cause Nazi-related accounts to be blocked from view.

title: Is This 'LGGBDTTTIQQAAPP' Inclusiveness Training Session Flyer Real?
subtitle: A flyer at a Canadian school used the lengthy acronym facetiously to appeal to teachers who feel overwhelmed by the evolving language used to describe LGBTQ individuals.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows a flyer from the Elementary Teachers' Federation of Ontario for a 'LGGBDTTTIQQAAPP' inclusiveness training session.

title: Does the GOP Tax Plan Include a Tax Cut for Private Jet Owners?
subtitle: A proposal included in the Senate tax reform bill formalizes a longstanding IRS policy of not subjecting private jet owners to a
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The Senate GOP tax reform bill includes a tax cut for private jet owners.

title: Does the GOP Tax Bill Introduce Anti-Abortion
Legislation?
subtitle: The current GOP plan allows "unborn children" to be listed as beneficiaries of college funds, interpreted as an effort to legally define fetuses as people.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: The 2017 GOP tax overhaul plan includes language that attempts to codify

title: Sam Walton and Minimum Wage
subtitle: Account describes efforts by entrepreneur Sam Walton, the founder of Walmart, to evade paying his employees minimum wage.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: Account describes entrepreneur Sam Walton's efforts to evade paying his employees minimum wage.

title: Do U.S. Gun Deaths Since 1968 Outnumber Deaths in All American Wars?
subtitle: A popular claim about gun-related fatalities revitalized after the 2017 Las Vegas mass shooting is fundamentally accurate, with some allowance for imprecision.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: Since 1968, more Americans have been killed by guns than have been killed in all wars in U.S. history.

title: Kroger Grocery Stores Offer Free Fruit to Kids?
subtitle: Some Kroger grocery stores are offering children under 12 years of age a free piece of fruit to eat while their parents shop.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Kroger's stores are offering free fruit to children accompanying their grocery-shopping parents.

title: Did 'Liberal Feminist' Katie Hopkins Advocate 'Euthanasia Vans' for the Elderly?
subtitle: Hopkins, a British commentator known for making outrageous and sometimes morally bankrupt statements, made the comments in 2015.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Liberal feminist Katie Hopkins advocated for driving euthanasia vans around to kill off the elderly.

title: Was This House Saved from a Flood by an 'Inflatable Dam?'
subtitle: A Texas homeowner did protect his house from flooding by using an "inflatable dam," but it was filled with water and not air.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows an "inflatable dam" holding back the flood waters surrounding a Texas home.

title: Is FEMA Hiring 'Field Inspectors' and Paying Them Thousands Per Week?
subtitle: The Federal Emergency Management Agency confirmed that a flyer advertising high-paid jobs available through 31 August 2017 is real.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: After Hurricane Harvey, jobs for "FEMA field inspectors" paying between $2,000 and $5,000 were available immediately with few qualifications.

title: Did a Catholic School in California Remove Religious Statues from Its Campus?
subtitle: Conservative web sites accurately stated that the San Domenico school has removed some statues; but they exaggerated the extent of the removal and omitted crucial context.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In 2017, the San Domenico school in San Anselmo, California removed some Catholic statues from its campus in an effort to be more inclusive.

title: Is an Australian Company Turning Human Embryos Into Jewelry?
subtitle: An Australian jeweler creates small pieces incorporating ashes of unused embryos from in vitro fertilization.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A jewelry company is making jewelry out of unwanted human embryos.

title: Does Crayola Recycle Markers for Free?
subtitle: Facebook rumors about Crayola's marker recycling program were largely accurate, but the program is open only to schools in the U.S. (and parts of Canada).
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Crayola accepts boxes of "dead markers" for recycling at no cost to consumers.

title: Did an Australian Teen Get Attacked by Flesh-Eating Sea Bugs?
subtitle: The 16-year-old was likely bitten by an unusually large number of sea fleas -- not sea lice, as was originally reported.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: An Australian teen was taken to hospital with blood pouring from his feet after 'sea lice' attacked him after he soaked his feet in the water at a Melbourne beach.

title: Is
a Real Book from the 1890s?
subtitle: Two books from the 1890s contain seemingly eerie connections to modern-day politics.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Author Ingersoll Lockwood wrote the books "Baron Trump's Marvelous Underground Journey" and "1900: or, The Last President"  in the 1890s.

title: Marine Stabbed by Shoplifter?
subtitle: The tale of a shoplifter who stabbed a toy-collecting Marine and was then whomped by other Marines has been embellished for humorous effect.
author: Snopes Staff
statement: A shoplifter who stabbed a Marine collecting Toys for Tots was then whomped by other Marines.

title: Did an Oklahoma State Representative Say Rape and Incest are the 'Will of God'?
subtitle: Republican George Faught was put on the spot by fellow state representatives while defending his bill to restrict abortions in Oklahoma.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In March 2017, Oklahoma State Representative George Faught said rape and incest are the "will of God."

title: Is this Really an Electric Car From 1905?
subtitle: A photograph of the vehicle is real, but misdated.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows an electric car charging in 1905.

title: Flathead Lake
subtitle: A somewhat mislabeled photograph shows the remarkably clear Flathead Lake in Montana.
author: David Mikkelson
statement: A photograph shows the remarkably clear Flathead Lake in Montana.

title: Did Aunt Jemima Recall Frozen Pancake Products Over Listeria Concerns?
subtitle: Behind a sensationalist headline lurked real news of a product recall.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: In May 2017, Pinnacle Foods announced the "largest recall in recent times" of several Aunt Jemima products due to possible Listeria contamination.

title: Was a Dog Elected Mayor of Rabbit Hash, Kentucky?
subtitle: An unincorporated community in Kentucky has elected a dog as its mayor for the fourth time in a row.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A dog was elected as mayor of a small Kentucky town.

title: Does a New Tattoo Ink Allow People With Diabetes to Monitor Their Blood Sugar Levels?
subtitle: A viral meme describes a promising research project at MIT and Harvard, but so far it has only been tested on the skin of a dead pig.
author: Dan MacGuill
statement: A new tattoo ink changes color depending on a person's glucose levels, meaning people with diabetes can use it to check their blood sugar levels.

title: Crystal Griner and Steve Scalise
subtitle: A post lauding an officer for her role in saving Rep. Steve Scalise correctly described her sexuality but left out important context.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Crystal Griner, the officer who saved Steve Scalise, is a lesbian (and the congressman is anti-gay rights).

title: 741741: Crisis Text Line
subtitle: Teens (and others) can text 741741 from anywhere in the United States or Canada to talk with a crisis counselor.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Teens can text 741741 from anywhere to talk with a crisis counselor.

title: Did Sears Sell 'Free Palestine' Shirts?
subtitle: The department store chain removed shirts made by a third-party retailer following criticism.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Sears sold 'Free Palestine' shirts on its web site.

title: Do Household Printers Leave an Invisible Tracking Code on All Your Printed Documents?
subtitle: While not all printers do this, nearly all color laser printers - at the urging of the United States government - code hidden metadata into their pages.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Household printers leave hidden yellow dots that provide identifying information about the printer and the date and time the document was printed.

title: Did President Trump Visit a Pediatric Cancer Patient During Israel Visit?
subtitle: President Trump met with pediatric cancer patient Emilee Imbar, though he did not slip away from his planned events to do so, as some sites claimed.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump 'slipped out of sight for a few hours' to visit pediatric cancer Patient Emilee Imbar.

title: Saudi Arabia's King Salman Eases 'Guardianship' Rules Against Women?
subtitle: An order from the Saudi king allows women access to more services, barring a previous 'regulatory obligation' that requires them to have male guardianship.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Saudi Arabian King Salman has issued an order allowing women more access to services.

title: Was Trump the First U.S. President to Visit the Western Wall?
subtitle: President Trump was the first sitting president to visit the Jewish holy site, but other presidents visited before or after they were in office.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump was the first U.S. president to visit the Western Wall.

title: Are the 'Rainbow Mountains of Peru' Real?
subtitle: Although a photograph does show a real location in Peru, the colors of the mountains appear to have been digitally enhanced.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A photograph shows "rainbow mountains" in Peru.

title: Did Fox News Report That James Comey Resigned?
subtitle: Fox News erroneously reported that the former FBI director had resigned, but corrected the record when they received accurate information.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Fox News reported the former FBI director had resigned, when he had in fact been fired.

title: Does Health and Human Services Appointee Charmaine Yoest Believe Abortion Causes Breast Cancer?
subtitle: Yoest claimed there was sufficient research to back up the claim in a 2012 interview with the New York Times.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Department of Health and Human Services appointee Charmaine Yoest repeated the false claim abortion causes breast cancer.

title: Does Dolph Lundgren Have Multiple Scientific Degrees?
subtitle: A meme compares the educational backgrounds of 'Science Guy' Bill Nye and actor Dolph Lundgren.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Action star Dolph Lundgren has multiple scientific degrees.

title: Does Actor Jeff Goldblum Have a Food Truck Called 'Chef Goldblum's'?
subtitle: The Jurassic Park star was handing out sandwiches as part of a promotion for an upcoming film project.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Actor Jeff Goldblum has a food truck called "Chef Goldblum's."

title: Did the Daily Mail Delete a Story Reporting the U.S. Planned to Blame Assad for 'False Flag' Chemical Attacks?
subtitle: The British tabloid did delete the 2013 story, but only because they were forced to admit it was not true.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The Daily Mail posted, and then deleted, a story saying the U.S. had given the "green light" for a chemical weapons attack in Syria that could be blamed on Assad.

title: Was Baseball Player Moe Berg a World War II Spy?
subtitle: Washington Senators catcher Morris "Moe" Berg never made it into the Baseball Hall of Fame, but he was proud of his service to his country.
author: David Emery
statement: Morris "Moe" Berg, a multilingual Princeton University graduate who played major league baseball throughout the 1920s and '30s, lived a life of danger and intrigue as a U.S. military intelligence officer in Europe during World War II.

title: Are 'Sandfalls' in Saudi Arabia Real?
subtitle: A video seemingly shows the phenomenon of sand pouring over a cliff like a waterfall.
author: Dan Evon
statement: A video shows a 'sandfall' in Saudi Arabia.

title: Did Ballerina Franceska Mann Shoot an SS Guard at Auschwitz?
subtitle: Franceska Mann is celebrated for her purported act of defiance against Nazi guards as she faced gassing at a death camp.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: In a dying act of defiance, Polish dancer and Holocaust victim Franceska Mann shot and killed SS officer Josef Schillinger.

title: Is Dairy Queen Holding a Free Cone Day on 20 March 2017?
subtitle: Rumors about a "free cone day" at Dairy Queen on 20 March 2017 are accurate, at the chain's participating locations.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Dairy Queen is hosting 'Free Cone Day' on 20 March 2017.

title: Bills Introduced by Republicans While We Were Distracted by the 'Russian Spy Drama'
subtitle: Legislation advanced by the GOP included bills to terminate the EPA, repeal the Affordable Care Act, defund Planned Parenthood, and criminalize certain types of abortion.
author: David Emery
statement: Legislation introduced by Republicans during President Trump's first two months in office included bills to: terminate the Environmental Protection Agency; redistribute federal school funding via voucher programs; terminate the Dept. of Education; repeal a wildlife protection rule; repeal the Affordable Care Act; defund Planned Parenthood; establish a national right-to-work law; strip federal funds from sanctuary cities; criminalize abortion; and place new sanctions on Iran.

title: Can a Fetus Send Its Own Stem Cells to Repair Its Mother's Damaged Organs?
subtitle: Genetically distinct fetal cells can remain in a mother's body for decades after birth and can even incorporate themselves into her organs.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: During pregnancy, if the mother suffers organ damage, the baby in the womb sends stem cells to repair the damaged organ.

title: Did Trump Golf Six Times After Complaining About Obama's Golfing Habits?
subtitle: Images assert that President Trump went golfing six times during his first month in office despite frequently criticizing President Obama for golfing while in office.
author: Dan Evon
statement: President Trump played golf six times during his first month in office despite frequently criticizing his predecessor's golfing habits.

title: Did Ben Carson Say That Illegal Immigrants Caught Voting Should Lose Their U.S. Citizenship?
subtitle: "As long as we reward people who break laws, they will continue to break laws."
author: Dan Evon
statement: Ben Carson said that illegal immigrants who get caught voting should be stripped of citizenship.

title: Did Adolf Hitler Say the Nazism Could Have Been Stopped by 'Smashing the Nucleus' of the Movement?
subtitle: A popular quote about stopping adverse political movements is frequently shared without full context.
author: Dan Evon
statement: Adolf Hitler said that the only way that the Nazi party could have been stopped was if it were destroyed in its infancy.

title: Is WhiteHouse.gov Promoting Melania Trump's QVC Products?
subtitle: The First Lady's site bio included mentions of jewelry lines promoted by the shopping network.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Melania Trump's biography on the White House web site promotes her jewelry line.

title: Does FamilyTreeNow Display Sensitive Personal Information?
subtitle: Web sites like TruePeopleSearch and FamilyTreeNow cause alarm by displaying address and family information, but they aren't targeting specific groups.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A web site allows criminals to look up the personal information of police officers.

title: Turtle Misshapen Due to Being Caught in Rubber Band for 19 Years?
subtitle: A turtle now residing at a wildlife refuge in Los Angeles was found with a plastic ring around its midsection, giving it a figure-eight shape.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: A turtle grew into an odd shape after being trapped in a rubber band for years.

title: The Origins of Princess Leia's Hairstyle
subtitle: Following Carrie Fisher's death, speculation mounted regarding the inspiration for her Princess Leia's character's iconic hair buns.
author: Arturo Garcia
statement: Princess Leia's "hair buns" in Star Wars were inspired by those of a Mexican revolutionary.

title: Is Las Vegas Now Powered Entirely with Renewable Energy?
subtitle: The city of Las Vegas has met their clean energy goals and is powering municipal facilities and buildings with various forms of renewable energy.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: The city of Las Vegas is now powered completely by renewable energy.

title: The Tragic Life of Keanu Reeves
subtitle: You'll need a hanky to make it all the way through this sad viral video recounting the tragic life story of "Matrix" actor Keanu Reeves.
author: David Emery
statement: Keanu Reeves overcame a series of tragic events in his life, before and after becoming a wealthy movie star.

title: Chase and Wells Fargo Among Banks Financing Dakota Pipeline?
subtitle: JP Morgan Chase and Wells Fargo are just two of a number of major banks acting as lenders for the controversial Dakota Access Pipeline project.
author: Bethania Palma
statement: Wells Fargo and Chase are invested in the Dakota Access Pipeline.

author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Anyone bringing supplies to DAPL protesters at the Standing Rock Indian Reservation could be fined $1,000 for the attempt, according to the Morton County Sheriff's Department.

title: Donald Trump Brokers Deal With Carrier to Keep Jobs in America
subtitle: A widely-reported deal arranged by the President-elect with Carrier kept 1,000 jobs in the U.S., according to both parties.
author: Kim LaCapria
statement: Trump arranged a deal with Carrier that kept a thousand jobs in the United States.

title: Colorado Birth Control Facts

author: Kim LaCapria

title: Can Marijuana Help Heal Broken Bones?
subtitle: Several studies suggest that a specific constituent of cannabis could aid in the healing of broken bones, but the research is in its infancy.
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: Scientific studies support the conclusion that marijuana can play a role in healing broken bones.

title: Did the House Pass a Bill Letting Government Contractors Fire LGBT People?

statement: A woman set her husband on fire for molesting their daughter.

author: Bethania Palma

author: Bethania Palma

title: Gary Johnson: 'Forget Global Warming Because the Sun Will Envelop Us All One Day'

author: David Mikkelson
statement: Gary Johnson once said 'global warming is in our future' because 'the sun is going to actually grow and encompass the Earth.'

title: Do Muscular Cows Demonstrate Genetic Engineering Potential?
subtitle: Extremely muscular cattle are the result of genetic mutation and decades of selective breeding - but not technically "genetic engineering."
author: Alex Kasprak
statement: A muscular breed of
is genetically engineered to provide as much meat as possible.

subtitle: A video showing a chimp finding numbers on a screen is real, and part of ongoing research at Kyoto University's Primate Research Institute.
author: Alex Kasprak

author: Kim LaCapria

title: Obama Accomplishments

statement: Passengers on an airliner diverted to Cuba thought the hijacking was a

author: David Mikkelson

author: David Mikkelson

author: David Mikkelson
statement: A girl named Laura Buxton released a balloon that ended up in the hands of another girl named Laura Buxton who lived 140 miles away.

author: David Mikkelson

author: David Mikkelson
